etymologies: mid 19th century; earliest use found in Robley Dunglison (1798–1869), physician and medical writer. From French osphrésiologie from ancient Greek ὄσϕρησις smelling, smell (from stem of ὀσϕραίνεσθαι to smell + -σις) + French -ologie

definitions: Originally; †a treatise on the sense of smell and odours (obsolete). Later: the scientific study of the sense of smell.
